The precursor materials were sin­ tered at 900 C for 15 h, and then exposed to three different cooling processes including natural cooling (NC), quenching (QU) and liquid N2 (LN) quenching to 25 C. Of note, liquid N2 quenching method with rapid evaporation and extremely low temperatures (� 196 C) can freeze the samples immediately, providing much faster cooling rate and O2-free condition than normal quenching treatment. ICP-OES is employed to determine the stoichiometric ratios of NAFMO materials (Table S1), which are consistent to the designed composition. The SEM images (Figs. S1a–c) are collected to reveal the morphologies of the prepared materials, exhibiting similar irregular polyhedron shape and smooth surface facets. Moreover, all of the prepared materials present a uniform distribution of Al, Fe and Mn elements and are shown in the TEM and EDS mapping results (Fig. S1d-o). Nevertheless, NAFMO-NC, NAFMOQU and NAFMO-LN materials present the median particle size (D50) of 932.6, 756.5 and 742.3 nm (Fig. S2), respectively, indicating the pri­ mary particle sizes decrease and the bulk diffusion length reduces with the increasing of cooling rate. Additionally, the XRD, TOF PND and ssNMR results demonstrate that the prepared NAFMO materials through different cooling process present very distinct atomic occupancy, local structure and even long-range structure. As shown in Fig. 2a and S3, both of NAFMO-NC and NAFMO-QU materials exhibit a pure hexagonal layered crystalline structure of P2 phase with space group of P63/mmc (PDF#27–0751), while the NAFMO-LN sample presents a distorted P2 phase (denoted as P2’, PDF#27–0752), which includes the standard diffraction patterns of P2 phase and four new diffraction peaks. These four peaks are attributed to the orthorhombic distortion of P2 phase and the decreasing symmetry of crystal lattice, generating diffraction peaks at the relatively lower diffraction angle in comparison to the (110), (112), (113) and (114) peaks from P2 phase. Due to the ordered arrangement of TM ions during natural cooling process, two honeycomb-superstructure peaks appear at ~22 and ~32 of NAFMOLN sample [16]. Here, in order to further describe the degree of distortion, the definition of δ is showed in Fig. S4, which is consistent with previous report [30]. The ratio of lattice constant of NAFMO-LN is calculated to be bortho/aortho 1⁄4 1.799, suggesting a slight distortion compared to bortho/aortho 1⁄4 1.830 of the P2’ phase Na0.67MnO2 (S.G. Cmcm), and the degree of distortion, δ, is estimated to be 2.9% (for the P2’ phase, δ 1⁄4 8%) [30]. The high-quality TOF PND data were further collected to investigate the existence of cations vacancies in the TM layers for its highly sensitivity to the distribution of atoms [38]. Rietveld refinements were performed with GSAS [36] and the results of the refined fractional atomic coordinates and atomic occupancy based on XRD and ND are presented in Table S2 and Table S3, respectively, which are highly consistent with each other and with low Rwp values. These results reveal that the atomic occupancies of TM ions in the NAFMO-NC, -QU and -LN samples are 0.922, 0.964 and 1, corresponding to the TM vacancies of 0.078, 0.035 and 0 in the TM layers (Fig. 2b), respectively. Moreover, the full atomic occupancy of Mn ions is expected to generate the lowest Mn ions average valence to satisfy the charge balance in NAFMO materials, which leads to the unequal Mn–O bonds and ortho­ rhombic distortion in the NAFMO-LN sample (Fig. 1 and Table S4). Besides, the lattice parametersa, c and V increase continuously with the rising cooling rate (Fig. S3), due to the larger ions radius of Mn3þ (0.645 Å) than Mn4þ (0.53 Å). More importantly, as shown in Table S3, the continuously expanded extent of Naþ layers spacing indicates that the faster cooling treatment would facilitate the Naþ insertion and extrac­ tion. In summary, our above results reveal that the long-range structure of materials is highly relevant to the cooling process, and a faster cooling treatment can suppress the formation of vacancy more effectively and thus increasing atomic occupancy of Mn4þ/Mn3þ redox center in the TM layers. To thoroughly study the structure of the prepared materials, ss-NMR spectroscopy was employed, which is highly sensitive to the local and electronic environment of target nucleus. Previous works have concluded that the characteristic signal of P2 and P2’ phase with obvious orthorhombic distortion are at around 1250 and 850 ppm, respectively [34,39]. Surprisingly, as presented in Fig. 2c and S5, the 23Na NMR spectra of the three materials only show one resonance signal at 1200–1450 ppm, even for the P2’ phase NAFMO-LN sample confirmed by XRD and TOF PND results. The results indicate that such a slight orthorhombic distortion of NAFMO-LN sample have no detectable effect on the local electronic environment of Naþ. Besides, all the spectra show a signal at around 0 ppm due to the diamagnetic sodium salts. Despite the chemical shifts and peak patterns for these three samples are Fig. 2. The local environment of Naþ is highly affected by the number of surrounding Mn ions though Na–O–Mn pathways and the presence of TM ions vacancies increases the types of local environment. Moreover, a higher content of paramagnetic Mn ions will cause a stronger Fermi-contact interaction around Naþ and thus a large chemi­ cal shift [40]. The resonance of NAFMO-QU sample locates at a larger chemical shift than that of the NAFMO-NC sample (Fig. 2c), which further confirm Mn atomic occupancy of NAFMO-QU is higher than that of NAFMO-NC sample. Additionally, the resonance shifts slightly to a lower chemical shift for the NAFMO-LN sample than NAFMO-QU sam­ ple, owing to the much longer Mn–O bonds in orthorhombic distortion phase (Fig. 1 and Table S4) and consequently the Fermi-contact inter­ action around Naþ decreased. To further reveal the effects of different cooling rates on the Naþ (de) intercalation, dynamics of NAFMO-NC/QU/LN materials, T2 (spin spin relaxation times) were obtained by the Hahn-echo method and the fitted results are showed in Fig. 3a. For the paramagnetic solid-state materials, T2 can eliminate the influence of transition metal ions and the faster Naþ hopping rate leads to longer T2 value [41,42]. As shown in Fig. 3b, the T2 value continuously increases with rising the cooling rate and reaches the highest value of 103 μs for the NAFMO-LN sample, which is assigned to the largest Naþ layers spacing (Table S4) and the fastest Naþ hopping rate. Besides, the electronic conductivity, as another important param­ eter for evaluating electrode materials, was measured by direct-current polarization method, and the results are showed in Fig. 3c–d. The ob­ tained electronic conductivity of 3.812x10� 5 S cm� 1 for NAFMO-LN sample is higher than the NAFMO-QU sample (3.227x10� 5 S cm� 1) and much higher than NAFMO-NC sample (9.790x10� 6 S cm� 1), which may be attributed to the increasing contents of Mn3þ promoting electron hopping [37]. Thus, an excellent rate performance of NAFMO-LN sam­ ple is expected, due to the fastest Naþ mobility and highest electronic conductivity. The above results have shown that the long-range and local structure of materials are closely related to the cooling rate during the synthesis process. Next, the XRD patterns at variable temperature were performed for a better understanding of the structure evolution during cooling process. Specifically, the precursor was firstly heated up to 900 C for 15 h in air, and then slowly cooled down to each temperature point. As shown in Fig. S6, the XRD patterns reveal that the material at 900 C matches well with the standard patterns of P2’ phase, attributed to the low average valence of Mn ions thus leading to an orthorhombic distortion of P2 phase as commented before [29]. As the temperature decreases, the characteristic diffraction peaks (marked with “y“) of P2’ phase are reduced in intensity and they are consecutively shifted to slightly higher diffraction angles due to the contraction of ab plane. The fact corresponds the disappearance of the orthorhombic distortion and the increasing of Mn ions average valence. As the temperature is cooled down to 800 C and beneath, only P2 phase is observed and its diffraction signals fit perfectly the standard patterns of P2 phase, probably due to the fact that the crystal lattice tends to uptake oxygen in the cooling process [29]. The XRD data obtained at variable temperature fully reveal that the structure of the material subjected at different temperature during cooling process could be obtained by appropriately controlling the cooling rate, and the faster cooling treatment promote maintaining the structure of high-temperature (900 C). 3.2. Long-range and local structural transformations during (De) Sodiation processes In-situ synchrotron XRD was employed to track the long-range structural transformations of NAFMO-LN electrode induced by the (de)intercalation of Naþ at a rate current of 24 mA g� 1. As shown in Fig. 5a, the XRD patterns have been divided into four stages to clarify the structure evolution process more clearly. The (002), (110), (112), (113) and (114) peaks are retained during the whole process, corresponding to a quasi-solid-solution reaction rather than typically multiple-phases transition reaction according to the previous reports [45,46]. As indi­ cated above, the prepared electrode is assigned to a P20I phase, which exhibits a slight orthorhombic distortion from P2 phase. At the begin­ ning of charge process, the (020) peak reduces in intensity and shifts to higher angle, corresponding to the decrease of distortion degree, and a P2 phase is formed at x 1⁄4 0.40. Afterwards, a board peak is observed at the higher diffraction angle of 9 at the end of charge process, owing to the formation of small amount of O-type stacking in the P2 structure. As reported by Bruce’s group, this process should be indicated as a “Z” phase evolved by the intergrowth mechanism, which have been mentioned in many P2 compounds, especially those containing Fe3þ [35,47,48]. The formation of “Z” phase is more moderate than O2 phase at high voltage, as the lattice parameter changes are smaller in magni­ tude and less abrupt, leading to a stable structure and better capacity retention [49]. The structural evolution is highly reversible during discharge. Of note, the (002), (110), (112), (113) and (114) peaks of P2 phase maintain in the rest of the discharge process, rather than replaced by that of typical P2’ phase with high degree of orthorhombic distortion (denoted as P2’ II). As the x equals 0.79, the characteristic signals of P2’ II phase are presented in both in-situ XRD and ss-NMR (Fig. 5b) results. However, such a moderate phase transition also makes it hard to distinguish between the P2’ I and P2’ II phase from in-situ XRD results. As shown in Fig. 5b, the local environment information of the elec­ trode materials can be observed through 23Na MAS NMR spectra, since Naþ directly participates in the electrochemical reaction in NIBs. 23Na 1D slices were extracted from 2D projection-MATPASS (pj-MATPASS) NMR spectra to eliminate the sideband signals [50]. Consistent with the powder sample, the ss-NMR spectrum of NAFMO-LN pristine electrode also shows the resonance signals at ~1250 ppm and ~0 ppm, rather than monoclinic and hydrated phases that usually occur during elec­ trode prepared process, suggesting that P2’ I phase is stable and structural transitions do not occur during electrode preparing procedure [34,51]. During initial charge and discharge processes, the chemical shift of the signal moves to the high and low value gradually, corre­ spongding to the increase and decrease of the Mn ions average valence, respectively. The local structural evolution is in good agreement with the results of in situ XRD. When the x 1⁄4 0.32, the amount of local environment significantly increases because of the glide of MnO2 layers, a wide peak at ~1100 ppm emerges, corresponding to the “Z” phase. Besides, the P2 phase signal can also be observed at the high voltage and decrease in intensity with “Z” phase emerging, which further proves the formation of “Z” phase is an intermediate and moderate process evolving intergrowth of P2 and O2 phases. The local structure is also highly reversible in discharge process. In x 1⁄4 0.78, the characteristic signal of P2’ II phase appears at ~850 ppm, which are clearly distin­ guished from the signal of P2’ I phase. Besides, the P2’ II phase signal of NAFMO-LN sample is much broader than that of non-doped P20-Na0.67MnO2 materials while similar to the stable P2–Na0.67Mg0.1Mn0.9O2 and P2–Na0.67Al0.1Mn0.9O2 materials in previ­ ous works [34,39], corresponding to a much more moderate structure transition and thus better cycle performance. 3.4. Effects of various doping elements on structural and electrochemical properties of materials In order to give some illustration on the significance of the work, the Mn ions average valence of layered oxide materias have been adjusted by introducting different valence doping element, e.g. the introduction of Liþ is expected to rise 3 folds molar equivalents of Mn3þ to Mn4þ, and 2 folds for Mg2þ and equal amount for Al3þ. Therefore, Na0.67M0.1Mn0.9O2 (M 1⁄4 Liþ, Mg2þ, Al3þ) and non-doped materials were also prepared via the same synthesis process to further reveal the rela­ tionship between the Mn oxidation state, structure and electrochemical properties. The longand short-range structural information are showed in Fig. 6. The obvious orthorhombic distortion of P2 phase can been found in non-doped NMO-QU/-LN and Al3þ-doped NAMO-LN samples with exhibiting the characteristic signals of P2’ phase in both XRD patterns and ss-NMR spectra. Also, orthorhombic distortion is observed for Mg2þ-doped NMMO-LN sample, just like the above results of NAFMO-LN sample. While the Liþ-doped NLMO samples do not show any distortion in both longand short-structure by each cooling treat­ ment. Besides, the full width at half maximum of P2 phase also become narrow continuously with the faster cooling treatment for each prepared material. The above results indicate that the orthorhombic distortion tends to exist in the materials with low theoretical manganese valence and TM vacancies can be suppressed for P2 type Na0.67MxMn1-xO2 by the faster cooling treatment, and then exhibiting a more uniform local environment. A comparison of the electrochemical performance of non-doped and doped Na0.67MxMn1-xO2 materials (Liþ, Mg2þ, Al3þ and Fe3þ) prepared by NC, QU and LN methods is shown in Fig. 6a–e. The initial charge and discharge capacities of all prepared materials increase significantly with the accelerating cooling rate, and the maximum capacity is obtained by liquid N2 quenching (LN) treatment for all samples, demonstrating that the rapid cooling treatment can eliminate Mn vacancies, increase redox centers, and effectively improve the capacity of P2 type Na0.67MxMn1xO2. Moreover, Fig. 7f and S13 show that the cycle stablity of Na0.67MxMn1-xO2 materials is highly related to the Mn ions average valence in the materials except for NAFMO-LN sample, which exhibits optimal electrochemical performance through the synergy effect of Al and Fe co-doping [32,33]. The lower Mn ions average valence causes more severe orthorhombic distortion in Na0.67MxMn1-xO2 and thus being detrimental to cyclability, e.g. the highest specific capacity (215 mAh g� 1, 2–4 V) but lowest capacity retention of non-doped NMO-LN (Mnþ3.33, δ 1⁄4 5.59%) sample, exhibiting many small plateau in galva­ nostatic charge-discharge curves. In contrast, the doped samples exhibit much smoother charge-discharge profiles, which evidences that the introduction of non-electrochemically active element disrupt the TM ordering in the TM layers and hamper Naþ-vacancy ordering during cycling [13]. The 10 mol% of Li-doping material presents a pure P2 phase without any lattice distortion and a stable cycling performance. However, even with liquid N2 quenched treatment, NLMO-LN (Mnþ3.59, δ 1⁄4 0%) sample only delivers specific capacity of 130 mAh g� 1. There­ fore, a rational element substitution should be implemented to mitigate Jahn-Teller effect and make a balance bewteen the capacity and cycle stablity to achieve superior electrochemical performance. Thus, the optimal co-doped NAFMO-LN material, with moderate initial Mn ions valence (Mnþ3.39) and slight distortion (δ 1⁄4 2.91%), shows not only an outstanding capacity of 202 mAh g� 1 at voltage range of 2–4 V, but also a satifactory cyclability of 90.4% after 30 cycles at 12 mA g� 1. 4. Conclusion In summary, our comparative results obtained in Na cells of nondoped and doped Na0.67MxMn1-xO2 materials with Liþ, Mg2þ, Al3þ and Fe3þ prepared via different cooling processes is verified by using the combination of in-situ synchrotron XRD, TOF PND and ss-NMR mea­ surements. Nano Energy 76 (2020) 104997 10 could be regarded as a genaral synergetic strategy to control the for­ mation of vacancy in TM layers and thus to enhance Mn4þ/Mn3þ redox center. Consequently, the deliverable capacity of all the Mn-based Na0.67MxMn1-xO2 materials can be signifcantly improved below 4.0 V, eliminating the factors responsible of capacity dacay such as electrolyte decomposition, structural collapse and oxygen loss at high voltgate. The ss-NMR, GITT and direct-current polarization results demonstrate the highest Naþ mobility and electronic conductivity for the liquid N2 quenching sample, among the three different cooling rate samples. Moreover, we introduced Al and Fe, the top two earth abundance metal elements into TM layers to form the cost-effective Na0.67Al0.1­ Fe0.05Mn0.85O2 compound. After liquid N2 quenching, the slightly dis­ torted Na0.67Al0.1Fe0.05Mn0.85O2 delivers a remarkable capacity of 202 and 246 mAh g� 1 within 2.0–4.0 V and 1.5–4.5 V, respectively. Even with 100 times higher current density (1200 mA g� 1), the specific capacity remains up to 122 mAh g� 1 over 600 cycles with 81% capacity retention, indicating exceptional rate and power capabilities with excellent cycling stability. The outstanding overall performance of Na0.67Al0.1Fe0.05Mn0.2 material demonstrated the synergetic strategy of liquid N2 quenching treatment and rational element substitution, which can be used as a general guide for the further development of high ca­ pacity, high power and stable cycling materials, especially for Mn-based layered electrodes in NIBs. Paul Dirac Drive, Tallahassee, FL, 32310, United States A R T I C L E I N F O Keywords: Sodium-ion batteries Na0.67MnO2 Liquid N2 quenching Manganese vacancies Solid-state NMR spectroscopy A B S T R A C T Mn-based layered oxides as one of the most promising and cost-effective cathode candidates for sodium-ion batteries still face great challenge to achieve high capacity with long cycle life under high-rate current simul­ taneously. In this work, we propose an effective strategy by a combination of liquid N2 quenching and aliovalent doping to get new layered cathode materials. As evidenced by in-situ synchrotron X-ray diffraction, time-of-flight powder neutron diffraction and solid-state 23Na nuclear magnetic resonance techniques, the proposed synthesis methods allow tuning the transition metal ions vacancies and enhance Mn4þ/Mn3þ redox center of P2-type Mnbased materials. Our results demonstrate that such an optimized structure significantly enhances the deliverable capacity, Naþ mobility and electronic conductivity of the materials. Furthermore, the effects of aliovalent doping elements and different cooling approaches on the long-range structure, local environment and electrochemical performance are comprehensively studied by comparing a wide range of doped Na0.67MxMn1-xO2 (M 1⁄4 Li, Mg, Al, Fe) materials. The optimized Na0.67Al0.1Fe0.05Mn0.85O2 material exhibits a remarkably high initial capacity of 202 mAh g� 1 among ever reported P2-type layered oxides within 2–4 V, a stable capacity retention of 81% after 600 cycles and outstanding rate capability of the specific capacity up to 122 mAh g� 1 at 1200 mA g� 1. 1. Introduction The rapid development of intelligent and environmental-friendly industrial technology, including smart mobile phone and green elec­ tric vehicles, has made rechargeable batteries an indispensable part of our modern society [1,2]. Among various energy storage systems, lithium ion batteries (LIBs) with superior high energy and power den­ sities performance have accounted for the key position [3]. Neverthe­ less, the low reserve and uneven distribution of Li resources, and the use of high-cost and toxicity of Co and Ni as redox center for mostly LIBs cathode materials fail to fulfill demands of sustainable development [4]. Recently, sodium ion batteries (NIBs) have attracted many interests and are considered as the most promising candidate of LIBs, due to the fact that sodium possesses similar chemical properties and higher natural abundance than lithium [5,6]. In the development of NIBs, cathode is the most critical component that restricts cost and energy density in the full batteries [7,8]. Comparing to polyanionic and tunnel-type cathodes materials for NIBs, layered transition metal oxides (NaxMO2, M 1⁄4 transition metal) are extensively studied because of their high theoretical specific capacity * Corresponding author. Among them, the low-cost Mn-based layered materials are deemed as ideal cathodes for large-scale energy storage. Two types of stacking structures, O3(ABCABC stacking) and P2(AABB stacking) are frequently observed in most of as-synthesized NaxMnO2 materials within layered structure materials [10]. In comparison to the (de)sodiation of O3-type materials via the interstitial tetrahedral sites with relatively higher hopping energy from one octahedral site to another, the P2-type phase allows a direct migration between adjacent prismatic sites, thus enabling rapid Naþ transport and showing better applicability [11]. However, the available capacities of P2-type cathode materials are still insufficient yet [12,13]. To address this issue, anionic redox reaction is introduced as its Li counterpart, which can be triggered to get extra capacity by charging the cells to a higher voltage range of 4.0–4.5 V vs. Naþ/Na (4.3–4.8 V vs. Liþ/Li). Unfortunately, the cathode materials inevitably suffer from electrolyte decomposition, multiple phase transition and even oxygen loss at such a high voltage, resulting in obvious voltage hysteresis and rapid capacity fade [14–17]. In contrast, controlling the cut-off voltage lower than 4 V for P2-type cathode can effectively eliminate aforementioned shortages and yield a much better cyclability, but the reversible capacity is hardly higher than 175 mAh g� 1 [18–22]. Recent investigations have focused on the optimization of the crys­ talline/local structures and morphology engineering of NaxMnO2 by adjusting the Na/Mn ratio, sintering temperature, cooling rate and aliovalent doping [20–25], which further determine the electrochemical performance. However, the overall performance of the materials is far below our expectation. The understanding of underlying structure-property relationship of the materials, especially the local environment including Mn vacancies, is insufficient for obtaining the material with high capacity and long cycle performance. The formation of Mn vacancies in the transition metal (TM) layers have been observed over 40 years [26–29]. Parant et al. proposed that Na0.67MnO2 is able to uptake oxygen during the cooling process [27], resulting in the lift of Mn ions oxidation state and the formation of manganese deficient phases (denoted as □): Na0.67MnO2 þ y/2 O2 → Na0.67MnO2þy (Na0.67/(1þy/2)Mn1/(1þy/2)□(y/2)/(1þy/ 2)O2) The thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) results of Dahn’s group showed a reversible mass gain and decline which are related to the oxygen uptake and release during cooling and heating, respectively [29]. The above works demonstrated that Mn vacancies are inclined to form during cooling process and then adjust the valence of Mn ions. Moreover, previous work has implied that a high-temperature quench­ ing treatment is possibly conducive to eliminate the Mn vacancies, which was reported by Komaba’s group designing distorted P20-Na0.67MnO2 with higher capacity than undistorted P2–Na0.67MnO2 [30], which represent a reasonable approach to synthesize a high-capacity Mn-based cathode material for NIBs [31–33]. However, such quenched samples still contain high content of Mn3þ ions entailing the notorious Jahn-Teller effect and thus multiphase transition during cycling and the enhanced long cycle performance of the material is missing in the work. Besides, a comprehensive study of the correlation between the cooling treatment and the structure of the material is also lacking. In this work, we propose a new approach to prepare Mn vacanciesfree Mn-based layered oxides cathode materials through a liquid N2 treatment. The rapid evaporation and extremely low temperatures (� 196 C) of liquid N2 take the thermal energy away and freeze the material immediately, providing a superior quenching method to affect the inherent properties/structure of Mn-based layered oxides materials and further improve the specific capacity. Besides, an efficient strategy through low-cost Al and Fe co-doping is introduced to adjust the average valence of Mn ions and suppress biphasic structural transformations during Naþ (de)intercalation [33,35]. The stronger Al–O bonding is beneficial to enlarging the spacing between the Naþ layers and stabilize the Na0.67MnO2 structure as demonstrated in our previous work [35]. And a small amount of Fe-doping is confirmed to disrupt cations ordering and moderate the transition of P2–O2 phases at high voltage, thus significantly enhancing cyclability of materials [33,35]. Accord­ ingly, an optimized low-cost Na0.67Al0.1Fe0.05Mn0.9O2 material with both superior capacity and cycle performance is successfully prepared through this synergetic strategy including liquid N2 quenching and aliovalent doping. Moreover, a systematic study on the correlation between the elec­ trochemical properties, long-range structure and local environment including the Mn ions average valence and structural distortion of the Na0.67MxMn1-xO2 (M 1⁄4 Liþ, Mg2þ, Al3þ and Fe3þ) materials via doping and different cooling processes (natural cooling, normal quenching and liquid N2 quenching) is further understood by employing exand in-situ synchrotron X-ray diffraction (XRD), solid state nuclear magnetic reso­ nance (ss-NMR) and time-of-flight powder neutron diffraction (TOF PND). The results clearly reveal the superiority of the liquid N2 quenching treatment, which can totally avoid the formation of TM va­ cancies and increase the atomic occupancy of Mn4þ/Mn3þ redox center, thus leading to the highest specific capacity, Naþ mobility and electronic conductivity among the prepared samples. Furthermore, the influence of doping on the Mn ions average valence, degree of structural distortion and electrochemical properties is discussed in depth. As a result, our work poses the most fertile directions in the development of high energy and stable cycling NIBs cathode materials based on sustainable Mn element, and provides an ultrahigh performance and low-cost cathode material for NIBs. 2. Experimental section 2.1. Synthesis of materials The Na0.67MnO2, Na0.67M0.1Mn0.9O2 (M 1⁄4 Liþ, Mg2þ, Al3þ) and Na0.67Al0.1Fe0.05Mn0.85O2 samples were prepared via a simple citric acid-assisted sol-gel method. A stoichiometric amount of NaNO3 (with 3% excess of sodium, AR,  99%), Mn(CH3COO)24H2O (AR,  99%) and doped ions source were dissolved in 50 mL distilled water, and LiNO3 (AR,  99%), Mg(NO3)26H2O (AR,  99%), Al(NO3)39H2O (AR,  99%) and Fe(NO3)39H2O (AR,  99%) were used as Liþ, Mg2þ, Al3þ and Fe3þ source, respectively. Then the mixed solution was added dropwise into a citric acid solution, and NH3⋅H2O (28%) was used to adjust the pH value to 7–8. The mixed solution was heated to 80 C and stirred for 12 h to obtain a sol, then dried at 120 C for 12 h to obtain a gel. The mixture was ground and heated at 450 C for 6 h. After cooling down to room temperature, the powder was ground again and pressed into pellet, which was calcined at 900 C for 15 h in air, and then sub­ jected to natural cooling (NC, average cooling rate: 0.8 C min� 1), quenching (QU, average cooling rate: 79.5 C min� 1) or liquid N2 quenching (LN) to room temperature and finally stored in Ar-filled glove box. 2.2. Electrochemical tests Electrochemical experiments were carried out in 2032 coin-type cells. The working electrode was prepared by coating the slurry of the active materials, acetylene black, and polyvinylidene fluoride in the weight ratio of 8:1:1 using N-methyl-2-pyrrolidone as the solvent onto an Al foil substrate and dried overnight in a vacuum oven at 120 C. The Na disks were made by rolling sodium chunks into thin sheets, which were then cut into circular plates and used as the counter electrode, and a glass fiber was used as the separator. The electrolyte was composed of a solution of 1 M NaClO4 in propylene carbonate (PC) and fluoro­ ethylene carbonate (FEC) (95:5 by volume). The cells were assembled in an argon-filled glovebox. The cells were galvanostatically charged and discharged on a Neware CT-4008 battery test system at variable current X. Liu et al. Nano Energy 76 (2020) 104997 3 rates from 12 to 1200 mA g� 1 (1200 mA g� 1 1⁄4 5C). Rate capabilities tested by charging at 12 mA g� 1 and discharging at the current densities ranging from 12 to 1200 mA g� 1. For galvanostatic intermittent titration technique (GITT) analyses, the cells were cycled at 24 mA g� 1. The duration time for each applied galvanostatic current and rest was 5 and 50 min, respectively. 2.3. Material characterizations Rigaku Ultima IV and SmartLab-SE X-ray diffractometer were used to collect powder XRD and variable temperature XRD patterns, respec­ tively, using Cu Kα radiation (λ 1⁄4 1.5406 Å) operated at 40 kV and 30 mA from 10 to 80 (2θ) at a scan speed of 2 min� 1 or 10 min� 1. Timeof-flight powder neutron diffraction (TOF PND) was measured at the VULCAN instrument at the Spallation Neutron Sources (SNS), Oak Ridge National Laboratory (ORNL). The diffraction pattern was measured at the detector banks at 2θ 1⁄4  90, equipped 5 mm receiving collimators. Neutron powder diffraction patterns were collected in the high intensity mode (Δd/d ~0.45%) for a duration of 2 h under the nominal 1.4 MW SNS operation, and then processed using VDRIVE software. Rietveld refinement of the XRD and ND patterns were performed using a General Structure Analysis System (GSAS) program [36]. In-situ synchrotron XRD patterns were collected in a transmission mode at room tempera­ ture, using ion chamber detectors at beamline BL14B1 of the Shanghai Synchrotron Radiation Facility (SSRF). For in-situ XRD, a standard CR2032 coin cell with small holes in each side was used to perform the experiment. Morphological features of the samples were obtained using a Hitachi S-4800 scanning electron microscope(SEM) and a Philips-FEI Tecnai F20 scanning transmission electron microscope (TEM), oper­ ating at 200 kV. The exact compositions of Na, Mn, Al and Fe were determined by Optima 2000-DV inductively coupled plasma emission spectrometry (ICP-OES, PerkinElmer). The ss-NMR experiments were performed on a Bruker AVANCE III 400 MHz NMR spectrometer. The 23Na MAS NMR spectra were acquired using a 1.3 mm double-resonance HX probe at a spinning rate of 55 kHz with a Hahn-echo pulse sequence (90pulse – τ – 180pulse – τ) or pj-MATPASS pulse sequence. The 90 pulse length for 23Na was 1.2 μs and the recycle delay used was 20 ms. The 23Na chemical shifts were referenced to 1 M NaCl aqueous solution (0 ppm). The spin-spin relaxation (T2) were also measured by the Hahn-echo pulse sequence as a function of echo time. For direct-current polarization measurements, the fresh powders were compacted under 200 MPa pressure and subjected to various cooling treatments at room temperature. Both surface of pellets were polished and painted with aurum paste, and they were embedded in a stainless steel Swagelok cells to conduct electrical measurement [37]. The direct-current polarization measurements data were fitted by i 1⁄4 i∞ þ (i0-i∞) e-t/τ. 3. Results and discussions 3.1. Characterization of prepared materials A group of Na0.67Al0.1Fe0.05Mn0.85O2 (NAFMO) materials were Fig. 1. Liu et al. Nano Energy 76 (2020) 104997 4 prepared by a sol-gel method followed by a cooling process. The syn­ thesis process is illustrated in Fig. 1. The precursor materials were sin­ tered at 900 C for 15 h, and then exposed to three different cooling processes including natural cooling (NC), quenching (QU) and liquid N2 (LN) quenching to 25 C. Of note, liquid N2 quenching method with rapid evaporation and extremely low temperatures (� 196 C) can freeze the samples immediately, providing much faster cooling rate and O2-free condition than normal quenching treatment. ICP-OES is employed to determine the stoichiometric ratios of NAFMO materials (Table S1), which are consistent to the designed composition. The SEM images (Figs. S1a–c) are collected to reveal the morphologies of the prepared materials, exhibiting similar irregular polyhedron shape and smooth surface facets. Moreover, all of the prepared materials present a uniform distribution of Al, Fe and Mn elements and are shown in the TEM and EDS mapping results (Fig. S1d-o). Nevertheless, NAFMO-NC, NAFMOQU and NAFMO-LN materials present the median particle size (D50) of 932.6, 756.5 and 742.3 nm (Fig. S2), respectively, indicating the pri­ mary particle sizes decrease and the bulk diffusion length reduces with the increasing of cooling rate. Additionally, the XRD, TOF PND and ssNMR results demonstrate that the prepared NAFMO materials through different cooling process present very distinct atomic occupancy, local structure and even long-range structure. As shown in Fig. 2a and S3, both of NAFMO-NC and NAFMO-QU materials exhibit a pure hexagonal layered crystalline structure of P2 phase with space group of P63/mmc (PDF#27–0751), while the NAFMO-LN sample presents a distorted P2 phase (denoted as P2’, PDF#27–0752), which includes the standard diffraction patterns of P2 phase and four new diffraction peaks. These four peaks are attributed to the orthorhombic distortion of P2 phase and the decreasing symmetry of crystal lattice, generating diffraction peaks at the relatively lower diffraction angle in comparison to the (110), (112), (113) and (114) peaks from P2 phase. Due to the ordered arrangement of TM ions during natural cooling process, two honeycomb-superstructure peaks appear at ~22 and ~32 of NAFMOLN sample [16]. Here, in order to further describe the degree of distortion, the definition of δ is showed in Fig. S4, which is consistent with previous report [30]. The ratio of lattice constant of NAFMO-LN is calculated to be bortho/aortho 1⁄4 1.799, suggesting a slight distortion compared to bortho/aortho 1⁄4 1.830 of the P2’ phase Na0.67MnO2 (S.G. Cmcm), and the degree of distortion, δ, is estimated to be 2.9% (for the P2’ phase, δ 1⁄4 8%) [30]. The high-quality TOF PND data were further collected to investigate the existence of cations vacancies in the TM layers for its highly sensitivity to the distribution of atoms [38]. Rietveld refinements were performed with GSAS [36] and the results of the refined fractional atomic coordinates and atomic occupancy based on XRD and ND are presented in Table S2 and Table S3, respectively, which are highly consistent with each other and with low Rwp values. These results reveal that the atomic occupancies of TM ions in the NAFMO-NC, -QU and -LN samples are 0.922, 0.964 and 1, corresponding to the TM vacancies of 0.078, 0.035 and 0 in the TM layers (Fig. 2b), respectively. Moreover, the full atomic occupancy of Mn ions is expected to generate the lowest Mn ions average valence to satisfy the charge balance in NAFMO materials, which leads to the unequal Mn–O bonds and ortho­ rhombic distortion in the NAFMO-LN sample (Fig. 1 and Table S4). Besides, the lattice parametersa, c and V increase continuously with the rising cooling rate (Fig. S3), due to the larger ions radius of Mn3þ (0.645 Å) than Mn4þ (0.53 Å). More importantly, as shown in Table S3, the continuously expanded extent of Naþ layers spacing indicates that the faster cooling treatment would facilitate the Naþ insertion and extrac­ tion. In summary, our above results reveal that the long-range structure of materials is highly relevant to the cooling process, and a faster cooling treatment can suppress the formation of vacancy more effectively and thus increasing atomic occupancy of Mn4þ/Mn3þ redox center in the TM layers. To thoroughly study the structure of the prepared materials, ss-NMR spectroscopy was employed, which is highly sensitive to the local and electronic environment of target nucleus. Previous works have concluded that the characteristic signal of P2 and P2’ phase with obvious orthorhombic distortion are at around 1250 and 850 ppm, respectively [34,39]. Surprisingly, as presented in Fig. 2c and S5, the 23Na NMR spectra of the three materials only show one resonance signal at 1200–1450 ppm, even for the P2’ phase NAFMO-LN sample confirmed by XRD and TOF PND results. The results indicate that such a slight orthorhombic distortion of NAFMO-LN sample have no detectable effect on the local electronic environment of Naþ. Besides, all the spectra show a signal at around 0 ppm due to the diamagnetic sodium salts. Despite the chemical shifts and peak patterns for these three samples are Fig. 2. Nano Energy 76 (2020) 104997 5 similar, the full width at half maximum for NAFMO-NC (97.49 ppm) sample is significantly broader than that for NAFMO-QU (64.99 ppm) and NAFMO-LN (64.88 ppm) samples (Fig. S5), which indicates that the uniformity of the Naþ local environment improves when accelerating the cooling rate. The local environment of Naþ is highly affected by the number of surrounding Mn ions though Na–O–Mn pathways and the presence of TM ions vacancies increases the types of local environment. Moreover, a higher content of paramagnetic Mn ions will cause a stronger Fermi-contact interaction around Naþ and thus a large chemi­ cal shift [40]. The resonance of NAFMO-QU sample locates at a larger chemical shift than that of the NAFMO-NC sample (Fig. 2c), which further confirm Mn atomic occupancy of NAFMO-QU is higher than that of NAFMO-NC sample. Additionally, the resonance shifts slightly to a lower chemical shift for the NAFMO-LN sample than NAFMO-QU sam­ ple, owing to the much longer Mn–O bonds in orthorhombic distortion phase (Fig. 1 and Table S4) and consequently the Fermi-contact inter­ action around Naþ decreased. To further reveal the effects of different cooling rates on the Naþ (de) intercalation, dynamics of NAFMO-NC/QU/LN materials, T2 (spin spin relaxation times) were obtained by the Hahn-echo method and the fitted results are showed in Fig. 3a. For the paramagnetic solid-state materials, T2 can eliminate the influence of transition metal ions and the faster Naþ hopping rate leads to longer T2 value [41,42]. As shown in Fig. 3b, the T2 value continuously increases with rising the cooling rate and reaches the highest value of 103 μs for the NAFMO-LN sample, which is assigned to the largest Naþ layers spacing (Table S4) and the fastest Naþ hopping rate. Besides, the electronic conductivity, as another important param­ eter for evaluating electrode materials, was measured by direct-current polarization method, and the results are showed in Fig. 3c–d. The ob­ tained electronic conductivity of 3.812x10� 5 S cm� 1 for NAFMO-LN sample is higher than the NAFMO-QU sample (3.227x10� 5 S cm� 1) and much higher than NAFMO-NC sample (9.790x10� 6 S cm� 1), which may be attributed to the increasing contents of Mn3þ promoting electron hopping [37]. Thus, an excellent rate performance of NAFMO-LN sam­ ple is expected, due to the fastest Naþ mobility and highest electronic conductivity. The above results have shown that the long-range and local structure of materials are closely related to the cooling rate during the synthesis process. Next, the XRD patterns at variable temperature were performed for a better understanding of the structure evolution during cooling process. Specifically, the precursor was firstly heated up to 900 C for 15 h in air, and then slowly cooled down to each temperature point. As shown in Fig. S6, the XRD patterns reveal that the material at 900 C matches well with the standard patterns of P2’ phase, attributed to the low average valence of Mn ions thus leading to an orthorhombic distortion of P2 phase as commented before [29]. As the temperature decreases, the characteristic diffraction peaks (marked with “y“) of P2’ phase are reduced in intensity and they are consecutively shifted to slightly higher diffraction angles due to the contraction of ab plane. The fact corresponds the disappearance of the orthorhombic distortion and the increasing of Mn ions average valence. As the temperature is cooled down to 800 C and beneath, only P2 phase is observed and its diffraction signals fit perfectly the standard patterns of P2 phase, probably due to the fact that the crystal lattice tends to uptake oxygen in the cooling process [29]. The XRD data obtained at variable temperature fully reveal that the structure of the material subjected at different temperature during cooling process could be obtained by appropriately controlling the cooling rate, and the faster cooling treatment promote maintaining the structure of high-temperature (900 C). 3.2. The galvanostatic charge-discharge curves of the electrodes within the voltage range of 2.0–4.0 V at 12 mA g� 1 (0.05C) current rate are shown in Fig. 4a. As the cooling rate for the prepared materials increases, the following charac­ teristics of first cycle curves deserve special attention: (i) These three samples exhibit smooth charge-discharge profiles, confirming multiple phase transition and Naþ-vacancy ordering during (de)intercalation processes have been suppressed by the introduction of Al and Fe ele­ ments. While the plateaus at ~2.2 V and ~3.5 V become more obvious with increase of cooling rate, which are related to phase transition processes and will be discussed in the next section. (ii) The open circuit voltages (Fig. S7) of the electrodes decrease continuously with the increasing of cooling rate, corresponding to the decrease of Mn ions average valence. (iii) The initial discharge capacities are 131, 175 and 202 mAh g� 1 for NAFMO-NC, NAFMO-QU and NAFMO-LN, respec­ tively. They are significantly improved with the accelerating cooling rate. To the best our knowledge, NAFMO-LN material has shown the highest initial discharge capacity and specific energy density (~527 Wh kg� 1, solely considering the mass of cathode active material) among reported P2-type sodium oxides materials in the voltage range of 2.0–4.0 V. Furthermore, as the working window is expanded to 1.5–4.5 V (Fig. S8), the capacities delivered by NAFMO-NC, NAFMO-QU and NAFMO-LN are 210, 224 and 246 mA g� 1, respectively, while an obvious plateau attributing to anionic redox reaction appears at ~4.2 V [17,43,44]. As indicated above, the anionic charge compensation pro­ cess usually shows the poor cyclabilities and slow dynamics in both sodium cathode materials and Li-analogues, so we mainly focus on the working potential below 4 V. In order to meet the needs of the market of smart grids, the requirement for the discharge rates of NIBs is much higher. The rate capabilities were tested by charging at low current and discharging at various currents, the same as previous researches [33,35, 39], and the results are shown in Fig. 4b–c. NAFMO-LN electrode shows the highest capacities and stable cyclabilities at each current density, providing the capacities of 202, 191, 173, 161 and 148 mAh g� 1 as the discharge current densities are increased from 12, 24, 120, 240–480 mA g� 1, respectively. Even with the 100 times increase of the current den­ sity (1200 mA g� 1), the capacity retention is up to 60% (122 mAh g� 1), indicating excellent rate capability among the reported high-rate P2-type electrodes. The diffusion coefficients of Naþ were calculated from GITT results to evaluate the (de)intercalation of kinetics of Naþ during first cycle. As shown in Fig. S9, the geomean DNaþ of NAFMO-LN (2.474  10� 10 cm2 s� 1) is slight higher than NAFMO-QU (2.196  10� 10 cm2 s� 1) and is much higher than that of NAFMO-NC (5.107  10� 11 cm2 s� 1), which is consistent with the best rate performance of liquid N2 treatment sample. In addition, the cycle stabilities of the ma­ terials are also investigated at different current densities of 12 and 1200 mA g� 1 as shown in Fig. S10 and 4d, respectively. At the current density of 12 mA g� 1, NAFMO-LN electrode delivers the highest initial discharge capacity of 202 mAh g� 1 and the highest maintained capacity of 198 mAh g� 1 after ten cycles without any electrode modifications. Espe­ cially, the excellent reversibility and negligible voltage change are found in the charge-discharge curves of NAFMO-LN electrodes. Due to the excellent rate performance of NAFMO-LN, this electrode was subjected to further galvanostatic charged-discharged cycles at such a high current rate of 1200 mA g� 1. As shown in Fig. 4d and S11, it also maintains the initial capacity of 122 mAh g� 1 and the long cycling stability is achieved with the remarkable capacity retentions of 98% after 100 cycles, 95% after 200 cycles and 81% after 600 cycles at 1200 mA g� 1 with ~100% coulombic efficiency during cycling. The plateaus of ~2.2 V and ~3.5 V are substantial reduction from the comparison dQ/dV curves at low (12 mA g� 1) and high (1200 mA g� 1) current densities, especially the plateau at low voltage which is deemed as the main reason for the ca­ pacity decays due to the notorious Mn3þ Jahn-Teller effects. Ex-situ 23Na NMR was further performed to explore the structure evolutions at high current density. Na contents are rep­ resented by x and shown on the left of each spectrum. X. Liu et al. Nano Energy 76 (2020) 104997 8 3.3. Long-range and local structural transformations during (De) Sodiation processes In-situ synchrotron XRD was employed to track the long-range structural transformations of NAFMO-LN electrode induced by the (de)intercalation of Naþ at a rate current of 24 mA g� 1. As shown in Fig. 5a, the XRD patterns have been divided into four stages to clarify the structure evolution process more clearly. The (002), (110), (112), (113) and (114) peaks are retained during the whole process, corresponding to a quasi-solid-solution reaction rather than typically multiple-phases transition reaction according to the previous reports [45,46]. As indi­ cated above, the prepared electrode is assigned to a P20I phase, which exhibits a slight orthorhombic distortion from P2 phase. At the begin­ ning of charge process, the (020) peak reduces in intensity and shifts to higher angle, corresponding to the decrease of distortion degree, and a P2 phase is formed at x 1⁄4 0.40. Afterwards, a board peak is observed at the higher diffraction angle of 9 at the end of charge process, owing to the formation of small amount of O-type stacking in the P2 structure. As reported by Bruce’s group, this process should be indicated as a “Z” phase evolved by the intergrowth mechanism, which have been mentioned in many P2 compounds, especially those containing Fe3þ [35,47,48]. The formation of “Z” phase is more moderate than O2 phase at high voltage, as the lattice parameter changes are smaller in magni­ tude and less abrupt, leading to a stable structure and better capacity retention [49]. The structural evolution is highly reversible during discharge. Of note, the (002), (110), (112), (113) and (114) peaks of P2 phase maintain in the rest of the discharge process, rather than replaced by that of typical P2’ phase with high degree of orthorhombic distortion (denoted as P2’ II). As the x equals 0.79, the characteristic signals of P2’ II phase are presented in both in-situ XRD and ss-NMR (Fig. 5b) results. However, such a moderate phase transition also makes it hard to distinguish between the P2’ I and P2’ II phase from in-situ XRD results. As shown in Fig. 5b, the local environment information of the elec­ trode materials can be observed through 23Na MAS NMR spectra, since Naþ directly participates in the electrochemical reaction in NIBs. 23Na 1D slices were extracted from 2D projection-MATPASS (pj-MATPASS) NMR spectra to eliminate the sideband signals [50]. Consistent with the powder sample, the ss-NMR spectrum of NAFMO-LN pristine electrode also shows the resonance signals at ~1250 ppm and ~0 ppm, rather than monoclinic and hydrated phases that usually occur during elec­ trode prepared process, suggesting that P2’ I phase is stable and structural transitions do not occur during electrode preparing procedure [34,51]. During initial charge and discharge processes, the chemical shift of the signal moves to the high and low value gradually, corre­ spongding to the increase and decrease of the Mn ions average valence, respectively. The local structural evolution is in good agreement with the results of in situ XRD. When the x 1⁄4 0.32, the amount of local environment significantly increases because of the glide of MnO2 layers, a wide peak at ~1100 ppm emerges, corresponding to the “Z” phase. Besides, the P2 phase signal can also be observed at the high voltage and decrease in intensity with “Z” phase emerging, which further proves the formation of “Z” phase is an intermediate and moderate process evolving intergrowth of P2 and O2 phases. The local structure is also highly reversible in discharge process. In x 1⁄4 0.78, the characteristic signal of P2’ II phase appears at ~850 ppm, which are clearly distin­ guished from the signal of P2’ I phase. Besides, the P2’ II phase signal of NAFMO-LN sample is much broader than that of non-doped P20-Na0.67MnO2 materials while similar to the stable P2–Na0.67Mg0.1Mn0.9O2 and P2–Na0.67Al0.1Mn0.9O2 materials in previ­ ous works [34,39], corresponding to a much more moderate structure transition and thus better cycle performance. 3.4. Effects of various doping elements on structural and electrochemical properties of materials In order to give some illustration on the significance of the work, the Mn ions average valence of layered oxide materias have been adjusted by introducting different valence doping element, e.g. the introduction of Liþ is expected to rise 3 folds molar equivalents of Mn3þ to Mn4þ, and 2 folds for Mg2þ and equal amount for Al3þ. Therefore, Na0.67M0.1Mn0.9O2 (M 1⁄4 Liþ, Mg2þ, Al3þ) and non-doped materials were also prepared via the same synthesis process to further reveal the rela­ tionship between the Mn oxidation state, structure and electrochemical properties. The longand short-range structural information are showed in Fig. 6. The obvious orthorhombic distortion of P2 phase can been found in non-doped NMO-QU/-LN and Al3þ-doped NAMO-LN samples with exhibiting the characteristic signals of P2’ phase in both XRD patterns and ss-NMR spectra. Also, orthorhombic distortion is observed for Mg2þ-doped NMMO-LN sample, just like the above results of NAFMO-LN sample. While the Liþ-doped NLMO samples do not show any distortion in both longand short-structure by each cooling treat­ ment. Besides, the full width at half maximum of P2 phase also become narrow continuously with the faster cooling treatment for each prepared material. The above results indicate that the orthorhombic distortion tends to exist in the materials with low theoretical manganese valence and TM vacancies can be suppressed for P2 type Na0.67MxMn1-xO2 by the faster cooling treatment, and then exhibiting a more uniform local environment. A comparison of the electrochemical performance of non-doped and doped Na0.67MxMn1-xO2 materials (Liþ, Mg2þ, Al3þ and Fe3þ) prepared by NC, QU and LN methods is shown in Fig. 6a–e. The initial charge and discharge capacities of all prepared materials increase significantly with the accelerating cooling rate, and the maximum capacity is obtained by liquid N2 quenching (LN) treatment for all samples, demonstrating that the rapid cooling treatment can eliminate Mn vacancies, increase redox centers, and effectively improve the capacity of P2 type Na0.67MxMn1xO2. Moreover, Fig. 7f and S13 show that the cycle stablity of Na0.67MxMn1-xO2 materials is highly related to the Mn ions average valence in the materials except for NAFMO-LN sample, which exhibits optimal electrochemical performance through the synergy effect of Al and Fe co-doping [32,33]. The lower Mn ions average valence causes more severe orthorhombic distortion in Na0.67MxMn1-xO2 and thus being detrimental to cyclability, e.g. the highest specific capacity (215 mAh g� 1, 2–4 V) but lowest capacity retention of non-doped NMO-LN (Mnþ3.33, δ 1⁄4 5.59%) sample, exhibiting many small plateau in galva­ nostatic charge-discharge curves. In contrast, the doped samples exhibit much smoother charge-discharge profiles, which evidences that the introduction of non-electrochemically active element disrupt the TM ordering in the TM layers and hamper Naþ-vacancy ordering during cycling [13]. The 10 mol% of Li-doping material presents a pure P2 phase without any lattice distortion and a stable cycling performance. However, even with liquid N2 quenched treatment, NLMO-LN (Mnþ3.59, δ 1⁄4 0%) sample only delivers specific capacity of 130 mAh g� 1. There­ fore, a rational element substitution should be implemented to mitigate Jahn-Teller effect and make a balance bewteen the capacity and cycle stablity to achieve superior electrochemical performance. Thus, the optimal co-doped NAFMO-LN material, with moderate initial Mn ions valence (Mnþ3.39) and slight distortion (δ 1⁄4 2.91%), shows not only an outstanding capacity of 202 mAh g� 1 at voltage range of 2–4 V, but also a satifactory cyclability of 90.4% after 30 cycles at 12 mA g� 1. 4. Conclusion In summary, our comparative results obtained in Na cells of nondoped and doped Na0.67MxMn1-xO2 materials with Liþ, Mg2þ, Al3þ and Fe3þ prepared via different cooling processes is verified by using the combination of in-situ synchrotron XRD, TOF PND and ss-NMR mea­ surements. Nano Energy 76 (2020) 104997 10 could be regarded as a genaral synergetic strategy to control the for­ mation of vacancy in TM layers and thus to enhance Mn4þ/Mn3þ redox center. Consequently, the deliverable capacity of all the Mn-based Na0.67MxMn1-xO2 materials can be signifcantly improved below 4.0 V, eliminating the factors responsible of capacity dacay such as electrolyte decomposition, structural collapse and oxygen loss at high voltgate. The ss-NMR, GITT and direct-current polarization results demonstrate the highest Naþ mobility and electronic conductivity for the liquid N2 quenching sample, among the three different cooling rate samples. Moreover, we introduced Al and Fe, the top two earth abundance metal elements into TM layers to form the cost-effective Na0.67Al0.1­ Fe0.05Mn0.85O2 compound. After liquid N2 quenching, the slightly dis­ torted Na0.67Al0.1Fe0.05Mn0.85O2 delivers a remarkable capacity of 202 and 246 mAh g� 1 within 2.0–4.0 V and 1.5–4.5 V, respectively. Even with 100 times higher current density (1200 mA g� 1), the specific capacity remains up to 122 mAh g� 1 over 600 cycles with 81% capacity retention, indicating exceptional rate and power capabilities with excellent cycling stability. The outstanding overall performance of Na0.67Al0.1Fe0.05Mn0.2 material demonstrated the synergetic strategy of liquid N2 quenching treatment and rational element substitution, which can be used as a general guide for the further development of high ca­ pacity, high power and stable cycling materials, especially for Mn-based layered electrodes in NIBs. 010916740: Contents lists available at ScienceDirect Journal of Alloys and Compounds journal homepage: www.elsevier.com/locate/jalcom Explore the effect of Co Doping on P2-Na0.67MnO2 prepared by hydrothermal method as cathode materials for sodium ion batteries Cheng cheng Fua,b, Juan Wanga,b,⁎, Yong Lia,b, Guoliang Liua,b, Teng Denga,b a Xi'an Key Laboratory of Clean Energy, Xi’an University of Architecture and Technology, 710055 Xi’an, PR China b Shaanxi Key Laboratory of Nanomaterials and Nanotechnology, Xi’an University of Architecture and Technology, 710055 Xi’an, PR China a r t i c l e i n f o Article history: Received 20 January 2022 Received in revised form 12 April 2022 Accepted 22 May 2022 Available online 25 May 2022 Keywords: Sodium ion Co Doping Structure stability Cycle performance a b s t r a c t Sodium-ion battery is considered to be one of the most promising candidates for energy storage systems. However, the energy density, rate performance, and cycle stability of sodium-ion batteries are still limited by cathode materials. To improve its electrochemical performance, we adopted doping Co at the Mn site to increase the proportion of Mn4+, suppressing the P2-P2 ́ distortion generated by Mn3+. Here, layered oxides P2-Na0.67Mn1−xCoxO2 (x = 0, 0.1, 0.2) prepared by hydrothermal method. The prepared cathode materials have the characteristics of uniform dispersion and obvious layered structure. The XRD refinement results show that the lattice parameters a of Co-doped material is reduced, but the layer spacing d is enlarged, which can be conducive to the diffusion of Na+ and the improvement of rate performance along with firstprinciples calculations has been used to characterize the charge storage mechanism. Moreover, electro­ chemical performance tests show that NCM2 has superior electrochemical performance. At the ampere density of 2 C, the material still has 88.7% capacity retention rate combined with excellent cycle stability after 200 cycles. © 2022 Published by Elsevier B.V. 1. Introduction For the sake of realizing the sustainable development of human society, the employment of clean energy instead of fossil fuel has become the requirement of contemporary society. In the wake of the rapidly growing demand for large-scale energy storage systems, electric vehicles, smart grids, and rechargeable batteries with high energy and power density are the most sensible choice for various energy storage technologies [1–3]. Electrochemical energy storage represented by lithium-ion batteries has become the main energy storage method now. However, lithium reserves are not abundant, and the increasing cost restrict its extensive and large-scale appli­ cation. By contrast, sodium is currently the fourth-largest element in the earth’s crust, and it is cheap. Therefore, sodium ion batteries are expected to replace lithium ion batteries in some specific energy storage markets, which can alleviate the shortage of lithium re­ sources to a certain extent [4,5]. Both Li and Na are alkali metals, the ionic radius of Na+ is larger than Li+ (1.02 vs 0.76) [6–8]. Recently, P2-type materials have attracted considerable interest because of their excellent cycling stability and rate capacity [9,10]. The layered P2 phase structure NaxMO2 with high specific capacity has received widespread atten­ tion due to its attractive price combined with environmental friendliness [11]. However, the expected electrochemical perfor­ mance for P2-NaxMO2 is often unsatisfactory. This is mainly due to the serious Jahn–Teller effect related to the Mn3+/Mn4+redox couple, causing the P2-P2' phase transition [12] thereby affecting Na+ transport kinetics [13]. A prime symbol (′) is used to indicate inplane distortion of the hexagonal lattice in the crystal structure, such as for P2-type [14]. The distortion reduces the Na+ mobility and further leads to structural collapse during repeated cycles. Therefore, further processing and optimization of structural stability are of great concern. Element doping is generally considered to be an ef­ fective measure to reduce the deformation of transition metal layer spacing and thus improve the reversibility of the structure. Where­ fore, understanding the effect of different doping elements is key to further develop and optimize NaxMO2 cathodes for NIBs. For in­ stance, Ni is used to providing high voltage to elevate the average discharge voltage [14–17]. Fe doping suppresses minor structural transitions during cycling and Fe3+/Fe4+ redox couple provides higher working potential [18]. Mg can stabilize the structure by suppressing structural deformation to the orthogonal phase, but the https://doi.org/10.1016/j.jallcom.2022.165569 0925-8388/© 2022 Published by Elsevier B.V. ]]]] ]]]]]] ⁎ Corresponding author at: Xi'an Key Laboratory of Clean Energy, Xi’an University of Architecture and Technology, 710055 Xi’an, PR China E-mail address: juanwang@xauat.edu.cn (J. Wang). Journal of Alloys and Compounds 918 (2022) 165569 incorporation of inactive Mg will affect the activity of Mn3+/ Mn4+ [19–21]. However, Co is an interesting alternative, which can be involved in redox reactions in parallel with Mn during the cycle. Wang et al. [22] have successfully synthesized P2 − Na2/3MnyCo1−yO2 by con­ ventional solid state reaction. However, diffusion of Na+ has not been adequately studied. Although P2-Na0.67Co0.5Mn0.5O2 prepared by Zhu et al. [23] has excellent cycle performance, NCM55 doped by 50 % Co doping is challenging for commercial applications owing to the expensive price of Co. Nicolas et al. [24] concentrate on improving the electrode performance of materials by regulating the mor­ phology. It was pointed out that the electrochemistry performance of the flake structure material doped was not outstanding. Konarov et al. [25] mainly conducted work on the P2-P2' phase transition. But we prove that Co has an advantageous inhibitory effect on the P2-P2' phase transition besides the improvement of Na+ diffusion used by lattice parameter changes and DFT. It is worth mentioning that, the flake structure with an obvious and uniform size prepared by the hydrothermal method can promote the diffusion of Na+ and accel­ erate the reaction rate. As far as we know, the influence of Co on Na0.67MnO2 is considered for the first time comprehensively and profoundly from the aspects of morphology, crystal structure, and electronic structure. In addition, although Co has a prominent effect on the improvement of electrochemical performance, the price of Co is relatively high. Using of less stoichiometric ratio is also a promi­ nent factor that must be taken into consideration. Here, Na0.67Mn1−xCoxO2 (x = 0,0.1,0.2) prepared by hydrothermal method have been studied as cathode materials for sodium-ion batteries. The Co3+ and Mn4+ were stable and randomly distributed in the transition metal layer. Most importantly, the incorporation of Co can effectively lower the Mn3+ with the Jahn-Teller effect and lessen the irreversible distortion of P2-P2 ́ material. Furthermore, the particles of NCM2 prepared by the hydrothermal method have high purity, and uniform particle size, which were conducive to the diffusion of Na+ and accelerate the reaction rate. In this paper, we comprehend the positive role of Co doping in the Na0.67MnO2 cathode using a series of electrochemical analysis methods. 2. Experiment section All chemicals used are received from Sigma-Aldrich without further purification. The precursor was synthesized by using am­ monium bicarbonate (NH4HCO3) as a precipitant assisted through the hydrothermal method. First, a certain stoichiometric solution of cobalt acetate and manganese acetate with a ratio of 1/10:9/10 was added into 30 mL deionized water and stirred to form a uniform solution, then a certain amount of NH4HCO3 was added into the above solution for uniform stirring. The resulting solution was put into the reactor. Set the temperature of the chemical reaction. After natural cooling, the hydrothermal reaction product was filtered and then washed three times. Vacuum drying at 80 °C for 24 h, the precursor was obtained and calcined at 500 °C for 6 h. After natural cooling, the precursor and excess 5 %mol of anhydrous sodium car­ bonate were fully ground in an agate mortar and calcined at 900 °C for 10 h, Na0.67Co0.1Mn0.9O2 (NCM1) was obtained, and Na0.67Co0.2Mn0.8O2(NCM2) and Na0.67MnO2 (NM) were prepared with the same method described above. The preparation diagram is shown in Fig. 1. 2.1. Materials characterization The phase composition of the composites was analyzed by X-ray powder diffractometry (XRD-700) made by Shimadzu Manufacturing Institute in Japan. The scanning range was set at 10°~ 80° and the scanning rate was 2°min−1. The surface morphology of the materials was characterized by an S4800 scanning electron microscope (SEM JSM-7610 F) made by Hitachi Company, Japan, and the distribution of elements was analyzed by energy spectrum analysis (EDS). 2.2. Electrochemical measurement The cathode electrodes were composed of 70 wt % of active material, 20 wt % of poly-vinylidene fluoride (PVDF), and 10 wt % of super-P. Sodium metal was applied to the counter electrode, whereas hard carbon was used as anode for the full cell. 1 M NaPF6 in an EC/DEC (1:1 v/v) was used as electrolyte. A glass fiber (GF/D) was served as a separator. The mass loading of active material was around 1.2 mg/cm2. The CR2032 cell was assembled in an Ar-filled glove box. Neware battery test system was used for conducting electrochemical tests performed with constant current between 1.5 and 4.0 V. The electrochemical impedance (EIS) test was the CHI660D electrochemical workstation produced by Shanghai Morning China Instrument Co. Ltd. The frequency of EIS test was 0.01 Hz~100KHz. The surface chemistry element composition was determined by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) (PHI QUAN­ TERA-II SXM). 3. Results and discussion Examination of the XRD patterns demonstrates that single-phase materials were obtained for all the studied compositions. This was confirmed by Rietveld refinement using the Fullprof suite Program (Fig. 2a-c). The materials showed a P2-type structure, crystallized in the P63/mmc space group. The diffraction peaks of all the samples are consistent with the standard card PDF27–0571[26]. Furthermore, no impurity peak is observed, which indicates that Co is well in­ corporated into the crystal lattice. The unit cell parameters a of Co doped materials are decreased with the augment of Co content but enlarges d spacing (Table S1). The Na-O bond of the Co-doped ma­ terial increases but the TM-O and O-O bonds are shortened, which makes the insertion and de-insertion of Na+ diffusion easier. The shortening of the TM-O bond and O-O bond is beneficial to the structural stability of P2-type materials [27]. Fig. 2d shows the shift of the base peak towards left as the cobalt content improvement, revealing the shrinkage of the TMO2. There is the lattice structure of layered P2 − Na2/3Mn1−xCoxO2 (x = 0,0.1,0.2) (Fig. 2d). The two tran­ sition metals(Co/Mn)are randomly distributed in the MO2 layer on account of the condition that Co3+ (0.545 Å), Co4+ (0.53 Å), and Mn4+ (0.53 Å) have similar ion radii[28,29]. It can be seen from (Table S2-4) that Co is smoothly doped in the transition metal layer. In P2 type structure, sodium ions at the prism site are supposed to pass through the center of a relatively wide plane quadrilateral con­ tributing P2 diffusion barrier that is relatively low, which can show excellent electrochemical performance [30,31]. As shown in Fig. 3a-b, the XRD test was performed on the NM and NCM2 after the 10th, 50th, and 100th cycles. It was found that NCM2 still maintains the original P2 structure after 20 % Co doping, but the pure material NM showed (022) characteristic peak of P2'. The same result has also been confirmed in the research of other Fig. 1. Schematic illustration of the preparation process of Na0.67Co0.2Mn0.8O2. C. cheng Fu, J. Wang, Y. Li et al. Therefore, Co can effectively inhibit the occurrence of P2-P2' phase transition, which is conducive to structural stability providing favorable con­ ditions for fast insertion and exsertion of Na+. For the sake of comprehending the morphology and structural characteristics of materials, a series of tests were performed to characterize the material. It can be seen from Fig. 4a-f that the particles of the three materials are all polygonal plate-like struc­ tures, with a particle size of about 1–2 μm, and the thickness of the sheet is within a few nanometers. The results are consistent with the XRD test analysis. The surface of the NM (Fig. 4a, d) material is not smooth, and the agglomeration is relatively obvious. In contrast, the surfaces of NCM1 and NCM2 are smoother and less agglomerated, which are beneficial to augmenting the specific surface area. It is conducive to the active material fully contact with the electrolyte, further accelerating the charge-discharge reaction rate [34]. In contrast, the particle size of NCM2 is uniform along with the layered structure is more clearly visible, the surface is smoother. The flake materials gather together to form some micropores, which is in favor of the full penetration of the electrolyte. In addition, a single uniform form can reduce the powdering of the electrode during the charging and discharging process, which makes for the stability of the structure. To analyze the element distribution in the NCM2 material, a plane scan of the elements was performed on the NCM2. Fig. 4g-k are the corresponding distribution diagrams of O, Na Mn, and Co respectively. It can be seen that the distribution of each element is uniform. It can be seen from Fig. 5a NCM2 presents a flaky structure, which is consistent with the results of the SEM image. In addition, we can find that NCM2 is a layered structure formed by stacking sheet-like structures. This result is consistent with the results ob­ tained by XRD. Fig. 5c is a high-resolution transmission electron microscope (HRTEM) picture. We calculated the interplanar spacing to be 2.48 Å. According to the PDF standard card in XRD (#27–0751), we know that the corresponding crystal plane is (100) plane. By analyzing the structure of the P2 type NCM2 electrode material, it is known that sodium ions diffuse along the two-dimensional plane perpendicular to the (002) plane during the charge and discharge process, and the direction perpendicular to the (002) plane is the (100) plane, that is, sodium Ions diffuse along the (100) plane. Fig. 5d is the electron diffraction pattern performed in the selected area of Fig. 4c. Analysis of the diffraction spots shows that NCM2 is a hex­ agonal material. In order to further explore the composition of element valence states, the material was characterized by XPS measurement. Fig. 6a shows the measured spectra of the three cathode materials. The peaks of P 2p, Mn 2p, Co 2p, Na 1s, and O 1s can be clearly detected, and there is no binding energy peak of other elements. The Mn 2p spectrum shows four peaks in Figs. 6b-d, 641.41 eV and 653.50 eV are Mn3+, and the other two peaks are Mn4+ at 643.0 eV and 654.5 eV [35]. Co 2p also exhibits four peaks, two of which are located at 780.22 eV and 795.20 eV are Co3+, and the other two peaks at 782.33 eV and 797.10 eV are Co4+. From Fig. 6e-f, it can be seen that the Mn3+ in NCM2 is significantly reduced. This is due to the Fig. 4. SEM images show the micromorphology of NM(a,d), NCM1(b,e), and NCM2(c -f). EDS contour (g). The cycle performance of the three materials at 0.2 C can be seen in Fig. 8a that the performance is related to the content of Co doping. After 100 cycles of discharge, NCM2, NCM1, and NM remain capacity are 153mAh·g−1, 119mAh·g−1, and 102mAh·g−1 respectively. Com­ pared with NM, the cycle performance of NCM1 is improved, but the generous effect is not achieved. It may be due to insufficient Co doping content. In contrast, the cycle performance of NCM2 is sig­ nificantly improved. This is largely because of that when the Co doping content is relatively enough. Low-state Co ions are doped at the Mn site, which can increase the ratio of Mn4+and reduce the Mn3+ with Jahn-Teller activity [42]. Fig. 8b-c is the charge and dis­ charge curve of NM and NCM2 at 0.2 C rate. It can be seen that NFM has a significant voltage drop at about 1.75 V related to the Mn3+Jahn-Teller effect with the increase of the number of cycles, which has a serious impact on the stability of the lattice structure of the material. After 100 cycles, the coulombic efficiency was 99. 8 %, 99. 3 %, and 98 %, respectively. Co doping improves the coulombic efficiency, which is beneficial to the stability of the structure and makes the insertion and deintercalation of sodium ions smoothly [43]. In terms of electrochemistry and structural reversibility, the high-rate charge-discharge cycle performance in the voltage range of 1.5–4.0 V has been further studied. Fig. 8d is a graph of the cycle performance after 200 cycles at a current density of 2 C. The initial discharge capacity at 2 C rate is 82 mAh·g−1, 98 mAh·g−1, 106 mAh·g−1 respectively. We found that with the increase of current density, the discharge specific capacity of NCM2 is lower than the discharge capacity of 0.2 C. However, the cycle stability of NCM2 after 100 cycles is more prominent, and the capacity retention rate is 88. 7 %. Fig. 8e are the charge and discharge curve of NCM2 when the current density is 2 C. The voltage fade is significantly suppressed for 20 % Co doping in the consecutive cycles. At the end of the discharge, the incorporation of low-priced and high-spin Co2+ makes the average combined state of Mn slightly higher than the level of 3 + , which can well inhibit the Jahn-Teller effect and benefit the stability of the structure [41,44]. Fig. 8f is the rate performance graph of the three materials. NCM2 still has a capacity of 137. 5mAh·g−1 when the rate is restored to 0.2 C. NCM2 has excellent rate performance and higher reversibility. The influence of different Co content on the electrode charge transfer kinetics is studied by the AC impedance test (EIS). In Fig. 8g, the diagram is composed of two semicircles, including diagonal lines in the high-frequency region and the low-frequency region. The high-frequency region of the real axis intercept represents the im­ pedance of ohmic resistance and the solution resistance, called Rs. The mid-frequency semicircle represents the charge transfer im­ pedance, called Rct, which is caused by the interface between the electrolyte and the electrode. The low-frequency oblique line re­ presents the impedance of sodium ion diffusion in the electrode, which is called Warburg impedance. Hard carbon is considered to be the most promising electrode material for sodium-ion batteries on account of its high sodium storage capacity and low sodium storage potential. As shown in Fig. 10a, in order to verify the practicability of the NCM2 electrode material for full cell, NCM2 was used as the cathode material, and hard carbon was used as the anode material in a mass ratio of 1:1.2 to match the full cell (NNCM//HC). The voltage range for the full cell is 1.4–3.9 V. NCM2//HC still has a capacity of 103 mAh g−1 remaining, and the energy density based on the cathode mass energy can reach 254 Wh ·kg−1 at 0.5 C after 200 cycles. The performance of NCM2//HC is outstanding, which is comparable to that of the matched by Zhao et al. [47]. The capacities at 10th, 50th, 100th, 150th, and 200th cycles are 147 mAh g−1, 136 mAh g−1, 124 mAh g−1, 115 mAh g−1, and 103 mAh g−1 respectively. In addition, manganese ions in NM exist in a mixed configuration of Mn3+ and Mn4+, but Mn3+ occupies the majority. While the proportion of Mn4+(t2 g 3-eg0) increased after Co doping. It is well known that unpaired electrons Mn3+ has strong Jahn-Teller activity, which can lead to lattice structure distortion and charge ordering, thus limiting the inter­ calation and deintercalation of Na+. Therefore, we conclude that the distortion of the Jahn-Teller effect for Mn3+ can be effectively wea­ kened by Co doping. According to the theoretical specific capacity formula ( = Q nF M ), NCM2 corresponds to 0.58 sodium release when charged to 4.0 V. In order to more fully comprehend the electron behavior during char­ ging and discharging, the PDOS are plotted in Fig. 11a-l. When Na is emigrated (Na0.5), the spin orbits of Mn and Co on eg gradually move from the left to the right side of the Fermi level. The shift indicates that Mn3+(t2g 3-eg1) is oxidized to Mn4+(t2 g 3-eg0) combined with Co2+ is oxidized to Co3+, and the charge compensation is provided by Co and Mn together in this process. When charging to Na0.34, the charge compensation of Mn have accomplished, and Co continues to play the compensation role until the end of charging. The electronic structure was further investigated and found that the strong cova­ lency between Co t2 g and O 2p forms an electron-deficient state or "hole" in the O 2p orbital, which is beneficial to inhibit the loss of oxygen, thereby improving the structural stability [50]. To further clarify the reason for the excellent rate performance of NCM2. Na+ diffusion of materials was investigated by First principles calcula­ tions using the NEB method. The corresponding Na+ migration bar­ riers of NM and NCM2 are shown in Fig. 11m and Fig. 11n shows the Na+ diffusion paths. Theoretical calculations showed that the ex­ cessive migration barrier of Na+ in NM is about 1.21 eV, which is much higher than that of NCM2 (0.58 eV). The results make clear that the Co-doping modification can promote the diffusion of Na+ and provide facile ion diffusion channels [51]. 4. Conclusions In summary, layered Na0.67Co0.2Mn0.8O2 for SIBs was successfully prepared through the hydrothermal method. Among the many P2 layered materials, we chose the low-cost Mn base transition metal Fig. 11. The electrochemical stability of Na0.67MnO2 is poor, which is mainly for the sake of Na+ / vacancy along with the slip of the MO2 layer during the process of sodium ion de-intercalation, causing the irreversible phase transition. The po­ sitive effects of Co doping on Na0.67MnO2 were comprehensively characterized by the morphology, crystal structure, and charge sto­ rage mechanism. Co doping at the Mn site increases the proportion of Mn4+ and Jahn-Teller effect distortion is effectively suppressed proven by DFT and XPS tests. Na0.67Co0.2Mn0.8O2 still has 88. 7 % capacity retention rate after 200 cycles at 2 C and the reversibility and cycling stability of the material have been significantly im­ proved proved by tests. Co-doping modification can achieve pre­ ferably cycle stability for sodium ion batteries.
